Due to the fact that the process utilized on site relies on the vapor lines, which are monitored for automatic shutdown on detection, and not the liquid feed lines, a piping failure on the tank would not allow for a catastrophic release.  The protection provided on this line is as follows.
1. The automatic shut-off valve is located less than one foot from the point of discharge from the source    vessel.  This keeps the total amount released at less than one pound.
2. The remaining piping sections are directly connected to the Chlorinators

The amount that may be expected to be released in a full tank failure could reach 120 lb./min, for 250 min., amounting to a total of 30,000 lb. only in the event of a total tank failure.  There is no adjacent equipment or processes that could affect the integrity of the tank.  
The vapor cloud could reach an end-point of 2.30 miles, but the model utilized takes all factors into consideration and places the bulk of the discharge into an area deemed as having the least population density, compared to the other areas within the end-point range.  The prevailing winds and the land configuration provide a positive, natural method for dissipation of a resulting vapor cloud.  As the model calculations state, the vapor would have to cross an initial levy wall, the Chain of Rocks Canal, a second levy wall, then the Mississippi River before it reaches any populated area.  The configuration of the levies, and contact with the canal and or river alone provide a plus in the control of the vapor.  It should also be noted that if the liquid were released into the sub-grade basement of the Chlorine building, any liquid entering the drain would automatically be re-routed to wet-well #2 an

d additional liquid would automatically go back into the treatment process of the plant, resulting in a high dilution rate of the Chlorine within the confines of the plant system.  The vapor would be confined within the building to a point, and escaping vapor would be controlled via the use of two-1 = inch fire hose, equipped with water curtains and or variable gpm fog nozzles.  These lines are positioned so that they may be placed where needed, utilizing the water curtains or handled by the on site Haz Mat team.  The Haz Mat team is made up of all persons assigned to the loading, and unloading of the Chlorine and also the Maintenance department and all management members.  The City Fire Department is also trained in the mitigation and emergency handling of Chlorine, including capping, plugging and control of one ton chlorine vessels.  In addition, a fire apparatus is kept on site so that it can be strategically placed where necessary in order to control the vapor cloud. 
The probability analysis model utilized was the Automated Resource for Chemical Hazard Incident Evaluation (ARCHIE)  The calculations were completed as directed by the Handbook of Chemical Hazard Analysis Procedures, jointly published by FEMA, DOT, and EPA. 
Although this scenario is highly improbable, due to the configuration of the system and the safety features, the scenario is recognized as a possibility.

Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The Granite City Regional Waste Water Treatment Plant has developed many strategies regarding chemical safety, both within the structure of the City Safety program and the site specific control factors.  The written safety programs utilized at the GCRWWTP that apply to the areas of chemical safety include the following.

1. General Safety Program
2. Hazard Communications / Employee Right to Know Program
3. Personal Protective Equipment Program
4. Respiratory Protection Program
5. Laboratory Safety Program
6. Hazard Assessment Program
7. Process Safety Plan
8. Emergency Response / Contingency Plan
9. Lock out / Tag Out (Chlorine line repairs)

Specialized training provided includes the following:

1. 1910.120 HAZWOPER for site Response Team and all Management members.
2. Full, on-site release scenario (at least annually), including local fire department, army base response persons, the LEPC and the local hospital.
3. Respiratory training including SCBA utilization in a full level A suit-up condition.
4. Fire Extinguisher training.
5. Utilization of on-site fire apparatus for release control, including chlorine vapor cloud disbursement, total flooding applications, fire fighting and victim decontamination.
6. Emergency shut-down procedures for release scenario. (at least annually)
7. First aid and rescue training regarding chlorine exposure for victim removal, treatment and quick response decontamination.




The management of the Granite City Regional Waste Water Treatment Plant is committed to the application of strong, time-proven strategies regarding chemical safety.  The on-site program is part of the City of Granite Citys overall approach to the protection of its employees and constituents against chemical exposure as well as other hazards.  The GCRWWTP falls within the regulatory scrutiny of the Illinois Department of Labor/OSHA as a public entity, and as such, complies with all

3. Replacement of the Chlorinating process with an alternative process.
4. Change of the air exhaust system with a higher exchange rate and
     a different location.
5.  New anchoring brackets for the bulk storage tank.

The Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:

The Granite City Regional Waste Water Treatment Plant is located on Illinois Route 3 & Niedringhaus Avenue, in Madison County, Illinois.  The physical plant is located within the confines of the Charles Melvin Price Support Center, U.S. Army Base.  The only regulated substance utilized on site in trigger amounts is Chlorine (CAS no. 7782-50-5), in a quantity not exceeding 47,000 pounds.  The material is stored in a sub-grade level tank within a controlled and monitored building.  The tank is an ASTME designed vessel with a design pressure of 300 psig and has a capacity to store 55 tons of chlorine.  Standard inventory is monitored by load cells.  The tank is equipped with a 225 psig Chlorine Institute approved safety valve which discharges to the building exterior.  Peak use during high storm water periods may reach 120,000 lb./yr.; where minimum use may only reach 60,000 lb./yr.  The material is used for chlorinating and treating of the waste water prior to discharge to the Chain of Rocks Canal / Mississippi River.  
The layout of the facility provides a positive vehicle for the control of a release due to the fact that it sets in a low-lying area, adjacent to a levy.  This allows for tracking and control of a low hanging vapor cloud, due to the prevailing winds in order to contain the cloud for dissipation and neutralization.  





Worst Case Release Scenario:

The worst case release scenario which could feasibly be encountered would be the total release due to a mechanical piping failure or tank failure of the main storage tank in the Chlorine building.  The failure of the tank is highly unl

f release would be handled by the on site Haz Mat team, and or trained members of the city fire department.  A one ton Chlorine response kit is maintained on site and all members of the team are trained in all aspects of the kit usage, at a Level A entry capacity.  As stated in the worst case scenario, the control of this type of release would be well handled and immediate.  The utilization of water fog application is expected to reduce the vapor by at least 50% in concentration.  The application of emergency control devices from the one ton kit would also allow for the control of a leaking cylinder.  Two privately held response teams are readily available for call-out response.  Both teams are within 20 miles of this site.  Countermeasures for vapor travel in other directions will be discussed in proceeding sections of this summary.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The Granite City Regional Waste Water Treatment Plant is governed by many regulations.  The following is a partial list of those that primarily impact the quality and completeness of our chemical safety provisions.
1. OSHA 1910.119 PSM
2. OSHA 1910.120 (HAZWOPER)
3. Employee Right to Know, Haz. Com.
4. Emergency Planning and Community Right To Know (EPCRA)
5. USEPA 40 CFR Part 68, CAA

The GCRWWTP utilizes many policies, procedures and SOPs in order to maintain a good prevention program.  The following areas make up a partial list of the guidelines followed.

Chlorine Tanker Unloading

1.  The Chlorine is ordered by the Assistant plant Superintendent.  He then notifies the U.S. Army base of the delivery time and date.
2.  The U.S. Army base is notified of the tanker delivery, and a post guard escorts the tanker to the unloading facility.
3.  Upon arrival of the tanker, the maintenance unloading crew sets up for 
     receiving the Chlorine.  All emergency response equipment is set at a 
     staging area in readiness.  This equipment includes SCBAs,

a one ton 
     repair kit, level A suits and accessible water lines.
4.  A vacuum is pulled on the system, and all process lines are isolated.
5.  The liquid lines are hooked to the tanker truck.
6.  At this point the valves are cracked open on the tanker truck on the liquid
     side.
7.  The truck and lines are checked for leaks using a baume ammonia
      solution.
8.  Once confirmation is gained on a no leak situation, the liquid lines
     are opened one full turn.
9.  The bulk storage tank scale is observed until an equalization is attained.
10.  At this point, air is supplied to the tanker, which forces the Chlorine
      into the storage tank.  A back-up compressor is utilized in order to
      assure that no chlorine is backed up into the air line.

11.  The flow rate of transfer (120 - 140 lb./min) is gauged until off loading is 
       completed.
12.  After transfer is completed, the bulk storage valves and transfer valves
      shut down and a vacuum is pulled on the system.
13.  Once a vacuum is established, the loading lines are disconnected from
      the tanker and are then capped off. 

The primary practices and installations utilized in the Chlorine process that most impact the safety of the system are as follows.
1. Written procedures
2. Closely followed routine.
3. Weekly inspections of all associated valves, piping and storage vessels.
4. Detection and monitoring systems that include the chlorinating room and 
     storage basement.  The monitors are read locally at the detection point and 
     at the plant monitoring station in the plant lab area.  These monitoring 
     points include the shut-off valves, tank lines, and chlorinators status.
5.  An on site weather station monitors specific conditions such as wind speed and direction,  temperature, barometric pressure, and rainfall.    
6.  Operating procedures are reviewed semi-annually in order to keep
     procedures accurate.  In addition, the procedures are practiced each time
     Chlo

rine is transferred.
7.  Low and high pressure is constantly monitored on the tanks, piping and
     loading lines.
8.  All liquid and vapor lines have built-in expansion chambers.
9.  The one ton cylinders on site are positioned so as to supply back up
     for the primary system.  The switch-over to back-up could be
     done instantaneously in the event of a primary system failure or problem.
10. Vapor release direction, because of a liquid release in the basement could 
      be controlled through the utilization of one or both of the exhaust fans in
      the building.  The controlled vapor could be diluted through applied water
      fog streams at these points.

11.  The primary storage tank is sonic tested bi-annually.






Five Year Accident History:  

No accidents have occurred in the last five years.  The last incident involved a tanker and occurred in 1993.  The release amounted to approximately 10 pounds.  No onsite or off site injuries or exposures resulted from this release.  A check valve was installed in the system in order to keep the same release from occurring.

The Emergency Response Program:

The on site emergency response program is designed to supply proactive measures as well as reactive procedures.  All employees involved in the Chlorine process, including maintenance and management are fully trained within OSHA 1910.120 (HAZWOPER), as are the Fire Department and EPC members who may respond.  
All detection equipment on site is remotely and locally monitored in order to notify all on site employees.  Upon notification of a release, the location is verified and an immediate inspection is made in order to determine the extent or immediacy of the release.  If the release can not be controlled and migration of the material is eminent, the following notifications are made.
1. All on-site employees
2. U.S. Army Base Security and the base fire department.  This activates the
